intro: Ophiorrhiza radicans, commonly known as the climbing mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its twining stems that climb on host trees, often in tropical and subtropical regions. The plant has small, opposite leaves and produces white or yellow flowers, followed by small, fleshy berries. It is adapted to nutrient-poor environments and relies on its host for partial nourishment. Ophiorrhiza radicans plays a role in forest ecosystems by providing food for various birds and insects.
